Comment: This is really fun! I solved this puzzle in Python, and the goal is clear, so it wasn't too hard to solve. It's good for a medium difficulty level.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Enonce clair. Jeux de tests bien dÃ©finis.
This is a thoughtful idea, turning a game we play in real life, to a puzzle.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: There is interesting problem that have many solutions with different approaches.

It was confusing for me at first..
I thought the provided list is what Alice and Bob have chosen.. But instead we need to make the right optimal decisions for them in order to have the whole chain connected (ending char. matches the prev. starting char.) until having potential leftovers that can't satisfy the conditions?
Maybe if we output the turn number would be better that signifies how maximum far we can get with the correct chain given a word list, that will also address the other concern of the forced loss of either Alice or Bob.

Maybe I am missing something but I think some of your tests are incorrect.

For instance shouldn't Alice win the league of legends test since Bob says "Legends" which doesn't start with an "e"? (same goes for the "16 words (validator)")

And doesn't Bob win the "More Same Letters" test since Alice doesn't respond?

Otherwise good puzzle.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple "minmax tree search" bruteforce game

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good task

this test is giving Alice, while I think its Bob:
4
ab  
bc
cd
da

The word chain game between Alice and Bob is quite engaging and strategic. However, one aspect that may be seen as less appealing is that when all words from the list have been chosen, the player who is forced to make the last move may end up losing the game, even if their move was optimal. This situation occurs because the game ends as soon as a player cannot make a valid move, potentially penalizing them for the turn order rather than their strategy or skill.

Output
* Please format "Alice" and "Bob" as {{constants}} instead of [[variables]].

Constraints
* Suggest to change "pairwise" to "all" ("pairwise" sounds very specific to meâ€¦).

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement, e.g. "write winner".

Cases
* (optional) I'll enjoy the puzzle better if the word list consists of real words only ðŸ˜›. Currently weirdly for some cases all/most of the words on a word list are of the same length.

Thanks.

Thanks for the feedback.
Turns out, it's actually quite hard to make cases where Bob wins!
I dont know why that would be a problem, it is one of the rules of the game that ensures someone will eventually win.
You put extra spaces after "ab". If you remove those spaces, the output is Bob which is correct.
Resubmitted!

Hello, 
The players do not need to choose the words in order. They can choose any unchosen word from the list. I changed test 1 so doing it in order will fail.
In â€˜More Same Lettersâ€™, Alice should begin with â€˜trolledâ€™ and win immediately.

Your understanding is correct, both players want to make optimal decisions to make themselves win (if possible).

Printing out the maximum turn number will often lead to the wrong answer. For example, in the first test case the longest chain is "cat -> toad -> dog -> goat" but this will make Alice lose. Alice will win if she starts with a different word making a shorter chain.

If it's confusing maybe it's better for me to change the wording. Let me know which part of the problem statement is ambiguous and I can rewrite it.

Hey, I agree with @Yasseruvski. The wording is confusing.
For me, it would be clearer if you would say 
> The players have a shared list of words to choose from, this consists of `N` words.
instead of 
> The players have a word list consisting of `N` words.
Thanks for this, Iâ€™ll update the wording.

Oh I see.
I thought the words list was in the order in which the game was played. That makes a lot more sense now. All good then.

So you loose even if you are not wrong. Also turns are allready fixed.
This does not make sense for me though.
I still don't understand what you mean but the point is, If one of the players has no way to win no matter what, then you should print the other player's name
